trans-unit.source: Convert WordPress to Multisite in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Convert WordPress to Multisite in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Learn how to take an existing WordPress web app created through the gallery in Azure and convert it to WordPress Multisite
trans-unit.target: Learn how to take an existing WordPress web app created through the gallery in Azure and convert it to WordPress Multisite

trans-unit.source: Convert WordPress to Multisite in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Convert WordPress to Multisite in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: By [Ben Lobaugh][ben-lobaugh], [Microsoft Open Technologies Inc.][ms-open-tech]
trans-unit.target: By [Ben Lobaugh][ben-lobaugh], [Microsoft Open Technologies Inc.][ms-open-tech]

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial you will learn how to take an existing WordPress web app created through the gallery in Azure and convert it into a WordPress Multisite install.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial you will learn how to take an existing WordPress web app created through the gallery in Azure and convert it into a WordPress Multisite install.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, you will learn how to assign a custom domain to each of the subsites within your install.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, you will learn how to assign a custom domain to each of the subsites within your install.

trans-unit.source: It is assumed that you have an existing installation of WordPress.
trans-unit.target: It is assumed that you have an existing installation of WordPress.

trans-unit.source: If you do not, please follow the guidance provided in [Create a WordPress web site from the gallery in Azure][website-from-gallery].
trans-unit.target: If you do not, please follow the guidance provided in [Create a WordPress web site from the gallery in Azure][website-from-gallery].

trans-unit.source: Converting an existing WordPress single site install to Multisite is generally fairly simple, and many of the initial steps here come straight from the [Create A Network][wordpress-codex-create-a-network] page on the [WordPress Codex](http://codex.wordpress.org).
trans-unit.target: Converting an existing WordPress single site install to Multisite is generally fairly simple, and many of the initial steps here come straight from the [Create A Network][wordpress-codex-create-a-network] page on the [WordPress Codex](http://codex.wordpress.org).

trans-unit.source: Lets get started.
trans-unit.target: Lets get started.

trans-unit.source: Allow Multisite
trans-unit.target: Allow Multisite

trans-unit.source: You first need to enable Multisite through the `wp-config.php` file with the **WP\_ALLOW\_MULTISITE** constant.
trans-unit.target: You first need to enable Multisite through the `wp-config.php` file with the **WP\_ALLOW\_MULTISITE** constant.

trans-unit.source: There are two methods to edit your web app files: the first is through FTP, and the second through Git.
trans-unit.target: There are two methods to edit your web app files: the first is through FTP, and the second through Git.

trans-unit.source: If you are unfamiliar with how to setup either of these methods, please refer to the following tutorials:
trans-unit.target: If you are unfamiliar with how to setup either of these methods, please refer to the following tutorials:

trans-unit.source: PHP web site with MySQL and FTP
trans-unit.target: PHP web site with MySQL and FTP

trans-unit.source: PHP web site with MySQL and Git
trans-unit.target: PHP web site with MySQL and Git

trans-unit.source: Open the `wp-config.php` file with the editor of your choosing and add the following above the `/* That's all, stop editing! Happy blogging. */` line.
trans-unit.target: Open the `wp-config.php` file with the editor of your choosing and add the following above the `/* That's all, stop editing! Happy blogging. */` line.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to save the file and upload it back to the server!
trans-unit.target: Be sure to save the file and upload it back to the server!

trans-unit.source: Network Setup
trans-unit.target: Network Setup

trans-unit.source: Log in to the *wp-admin* area of your web app and you should see a new item under the **Tools** menu called **Network Setup**.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the *wp-admin* area of your web app and you should see a new item under the **Tools** menu called **Network Setup**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Network Setup** and fill in the details of your network.
trans-unit.target: Click **Network Setup** and fill in the details of your network.

trans-unit.source: Network Setup Screen
trans-unit.target: Network Setup Screen

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses the *Sub-directories* site schema because it should always work, and we will be setting up custom domains for each subsite later in the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses the *Sub-directories* site schema because it should always work, and we will be setting up custom domains for each subsite later in the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: However, it should be possible to setup a subdomain install if you map a domain through the [Azure Portal](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529715) and setup wildcard DNS properly.
trans-unit.target: However, it should be possible to setup a subdomain install if you map a domain through the [Azure Portal](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529715) and setup wildcard DNS properly.

trans-unit.source: For more information on sub-domain vs sub-directory setups see the [Types of multisite network][wordpress-codex-types-of-networks] article on the WordPress Codex.
trans-unit.target: For more information on sub-domain vs sub-directory setups see the [Types of multisite network][wordpress-codex-types-of-networks] article on the WordPress Codex.

trans-unit.source: Enable the Network
trans-unit.target: Enable the Network

trans-unit.source: The network is now configured in the database, but there is one remaining step to enable the network functionality.
trans-unit.target: The network is now configured in the database, but there is one remaining step to enable the network functionality.

trans-unit.source: Finalize the `wp-config.php` settings and ensure `web.config` properly routes each site.
trans-unit.target: Finalize the `wp-config.php` settings and ensure `web.config` properly routes each site.

trans-unit.source: After clicking the **Install** button on the *Network Setup* page, WordPress will attempt to update the `wp-config.php` and `web.config` files.
trans-unit.target: After clicking the **Install** button on the *Network Setup* page, WordPress will attempt to update the `wp-config.php` and `web.config` files.

trans-unit.source: However, you should always check the files to ensure the updates were successful.
trans-unit.target: However, you should always check the files to ensure the updates were successful.

trans-unit.source: If not, this screen will present you with the necessary updates.
trans-unit.target: If not, this screen will present you with the necessary updates.

trans-unit.source: Edit and save the files.
trans-unit.target: Edit and save the files.

trans-unit.source: After making these updates you will need to log out and log back in to the wp-admin dashboard.
trans-unit.target: After making these updates you will need to log out and log back in to the wp-admin dashboard.

trans-unit.source: There should now be an additional menu on the admin bar labeled **My Sites**.
trans-unit.target: There should now be an additional menu on the admin bar labeled **My Sites**.

trans-unit.source: This menu allows you to control your new network through the **Network Admin** dashboard.
trans-unit.target: This menu allows you to control your new network through the **Network Admin** dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Adding custom domains
trans-unit.target: Adding custom domains

trans-unit.source: The [WordPress MU Domain Mapping][wordpress-plugin-wordpress-mu-domain-mapping] plugin makes it a breeze to add custom domains to any site in your network.
trans-unit.target: The [WordPress MU Domain Mapping][wordpress-plugin-wordpress-mu-domain-mapping] plugin makes it a breeze to add custom domains to any site in your network.

trans-unit.source: In order for the plugin to operate properly, you need to do some additional setup on the Portal, and also at your domain registrar.
trans-unit.target: In order for the plugin to operate properly, you need to do some additional setup on the Portal, and also at your domain registrar.

trans-unit.source: Enable domain mapping to the web app
trans-unit.target: Enable domain mapping to the web app

trans-unit.source: The **Free** [App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714) plan mode does not support adding custom domains to Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: The **Free** [App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714) plan mode does not support adding custom domains to Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: You will need to switch to **Shared** or **Standard** mode.
trans-unit.target: You will need to switch to **Shared** or **Standard** mode.

trans-unit.source: To do this:
trans-unit.target: To do this:

trans-unit.source: Log in to the Azure Portal and locate your web app.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the Azure Portal and locate your web app.

trans-unit.source: Click on the **Scale** tab in the main content area
trans-unit.target: Click on the **Scale** tab in the main content area

trans-unit.source: Under **General**, select either *SHARED* or *STANDARD*
trans-unit.target: Under **General**, select either *SHARED* or *STANDARD*

trans-unit.source: Click **Save**
trans-unit.target: Click **Save**

trans-unit.source: You may receive a message asking you to verify the change and acknowledge your web app may now incur cost, depending upon usage and the other configuration you set.
trans-unit.target: You may receive a message asking you to verify the change and acknowledge your web app may now incur cost, depending upon usage and the other configuration you set.

trans-unit.source: It takes a few seconds to process the new settings, so now is a good time to start setting up your domain.
trans-unit.target: It takes a few seconds to process the new settings, so now is a good time to start setting up your domain.

trans-unit.source: Verify your domain
trans-unit.target: Verify your domain

trans-unit.source: Before Azure Web Apps will allow you to map a domain to the site, you first need to verify that you have the authorization to map the domain.
trans-unit.target: Before Azure Web Apps will allow you to map a domain to the site, you first need to verify that you have the authorization to map the domain.

trans-unit.source: To do so, you must add a new CNAME record to your DNS entry.
trans-unit.target: To do so, you must add a new CNAME record to your DNS entry.

trans-unit.source: Log in to your domain's DNS manager
trans-unit.target: Log in to your domain's DNS manager

trans-unit.source: Create a new CNAME *awverify*
trans-unit.target: Create a new CNAME *awverify*

trans-unit.source: Point *awverify* to *awverify.YOUR_DOMAIN.azurewebsites.net*
trans-unit.target: Point *awverify* to *awverify.YOUR_DOMAIN.azurewebsites.net*

trans-unit.source: It may take some time for the DNS changes to go into full effect, so if the following steps do not work immediately, go make a cup of coffee, then come back and try again.
trans-unit.target: It may take some time for the DNS changes to go into full effect, so if the following steps do not work immediately, go make a cup of coffee, then come back and try again.

trans-unit.source: Add the domain to the web app
trans-unit.target: Add the domain to the web app

trans-unit.source: Return to your web app through the Azure Portal, click **Settings**, and then click **Custom domains and SSL**.
trans-unit.target: Return to your web app through the Azure Portal, click **Settings**, and then click **Custom domains and SSL**.

trans-unit.source: When the *SSL settings* are displayed, you will see the fields where you will input all the domains which you wish to assign to your web app.
trans-unit.target: When the *SSL settings* are displayed, you will see the fields where you will input all the domains which you wish to assign to your web app.

trans-unit.source: If a domain is not listed here, it will not be available for mapping inside WordPress, regardless of how the domain DNS is setup.
trans-unit.target: If a domain is not listed here, it will not be available for mapping inside WordPress, regardless of how the domain DNS is setup.

trans-unit.source: Manage custom domains dialog
trans-unit.target: Manage custom domains dialog

trans-unit.source: After typing your domain into the text box, Azure will verify the CNAME record you created previously.
trans-unit.target: After typing your domain into the text box, Azure will verify the CNAME record you created previously.

trans-unit.source: If the DNS has not fully propigated, a red indicator will show.
trans-unit.target: If the DNS has not fully propigated, a red indicator will show.

trans-unit.source: If it was successful, you will see a green checkmark.
trans-unit.target: If it was successful, you will see a green checkmark.

trans-unit.source: Take note of the IP Address listed at the bottom of the dialog.
trans-unit.target: Take note of the IP Address listed at the bottom of the dialog.

trans-unit.source: You will need this to setup the A record for your domain.
trans-unit.target: You will need this to setup the A record for your domain.

trans-unit.source: Setup the domain A record
trans-unit.target: Setup the domain A record

trans-unit.source: If the other steps were successful, you may now assign the domain to your Azure web app through a DNS A record.
trans-unit.target: If the other steps were successful, you may now assign the domain to your Azure web app through a DNS A record.

trans-unit.source: It is important to note here that Azure web apps accept both CNAME and A records, however you *must* use an A record to enable proper domain mapping.
trans-unit.target: It is important to note here that Azure web apps accept both CNAME and A records, however you *must* use an A record to enable proper domain mapping.

trans-unit.source: A CNAME cannot be forwarded to another CNAME, which is what Azure created for you with YOUR_DOMAIN.azurewebsites.net.
trans-unit.target: A CNAME cannot be forwarded to another CNAME, which is what Azure created for you with YOUR_DOMAIN.azurewebsites.net.

trans-unit.source: Using the IP address from the previous step, return to your DNS manager and setup the A record to point to that IP.
trans-unit.target: Using the IP address from the previous step, return to your DNS manager and setup the A record to point to that IP.

trans-unit.source: Install and setup the plugin
trans-unit.target: Install and setup the plugin

trans-unit.source: WordPress Multisite currently does not have a built in method to map custom domains.
trans-unit.target: WordPress Multisite currently does not have a built in method to map custom domains.

trans-unit.source: However, there is a plugin called [WordPress MU Domain Mapping][wordpress-plugin-wordpress-mu-domain-mapping] that adds the functionality for you.
trans-unit.target: However, there is a plugin called [WordPress MU Domain Mapping][wordpress-plugin-wordpress-mu-domain-mapping] that adds the functionality for you.

trans-unit.source: Log in to the Network Admin portion of your site and install the **WordPress MU Domain Mapping** plugin.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the Network Admin portion of your site and install the **WordPress MU Domain Mapping** plugin.

trans-unit.source: After installing and activating the plugin, visit **Settings** > **Domain Mapping** to configure the plugin.
trans-unit.target: After installing and activating the plugin, visit **Settings** > **Domain Mapping** to configure the plugin.

trans-unit.source: In the first textbox, *Server IP Address*, input the IP Address you used to setup the A record for the domain.
trans-unit.target: In the first textbox, *Server IP Address*, input the IP Address you used to setup the A record for the domain.

trans-unit.source: Set any *Domain Options* you desire (the defaults are often fine) and click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: Set any *Domain Options* you desire (the defaults are often fine) and click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: Map the domain
trans-unit.target: Map the domain

trans-unit.source: Visit the **Dashboard** for the site you wish to map the domain to.
trans-unit.target: Visit the **Dashboard** for the site you wish to map the domain to.

trans-unit.source: Click on **Tools** > **Domain Mapping** and type the new domain into the textbox and click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: Click on **Tools** > **Domain Mapping** and type the new domain into the textbox and click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: By default, the new domain will be rewritten to the autogenerated site domain.
trans-unit.target: By default, the new domain will be rewritten to the autogenerated site domain.

trans-unit.source: If you want to have all traffic sent to the new domain, check the *Primary domain for this blog* box before saving.
trans-unit.target: If you want to have all traffic sent to the new domain, check the *Primary domain for this blog* box before saving.

trans-unit.source: You can add an unlimited number of domains to a site, but only one can be primary.
trans-unit.target: You can add an unlimited number of domains to a site, but only one can be primary.

trans-unit.source: Do it again
trans-unit.target: Do it again

trans-unit.source: Azure Web Apps allow you to add an unlimited number of domains to a web app.
trans-unit.target: Azure Web Apps allow you to add an unlimited number of domains to a web app.

trans-unit.source: To add another domain you will need to execute the **Verify your domain** and **Setup the domain A record** sections for each domain.
trans-unit.target: To add another domain you will need to execute the **Verify your domain** and **Setup the domain A record** sections for each domain.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: What's changed
trans-unit.target: What's changed

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: [Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714)
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: [Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714)

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: [Reference for navigating the preview portal](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529715)
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: [Reference for navigating the preview portal](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529715)

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
